data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

other.value: Data have been collected in the Fall 2019 semester, but data have not been downloaded or analyzed in any way at the time of registry. Additional authors not included in this registry are Delaney S. Dunn, B.A., Emily A. Birkel, B.A., and Thad R. Leffingwell, Ph.D.

sample.value: The survey was available for data collection for any number of participants from August 2019 to December 6th, 2019. We recruited as many participants as possible during that time.

analyses.value: We will conduct 2 boot-strapped mediation analyses, one for males and one for females. For both mediation models, mating orientation will be associated with higher RSB patterns, and this relationship will be explained through heavier alcohol use.

outliers.value: We will exclude those who admit dishonest/random responding, those who did not complete the majority of the survey, and those who responded incorrectly on over half of the attention check items. Outliers on the DDQ will be replaced with values 3 standard deviations and 1 integer above the mean (Tabachnick & Fidell, 2007).

dependent.value: 1. Alcohol use, which will be self-reported as typical number of standard drinks per week (Daily Drinking Questionnaire; Collins, Parks, & Marlatt, 1985). 2. Risky sexual behavior (RSB) will be measured using the Cognitive Appraisal of Risky Events - Revised (CARE-R; Katz, Fromme, & D'Amico, 2000), which is a self-report measure that assesses frequency of risky sexual activity, such as sex with an unknown partner, in the past 6 months. Responses range from “never” (1) to “31 or more times” (7). Items will be summed to create a total score of RSB, with higher numbers indicating greater frequency of RSB engagement.

conditions.value: No unique conditions. Mating orientation will be measured as a continuous variable from short-term orientation to long-term orientation. Participants will complete the Sociosexual Orientation Inventory (SOI; Jackson & Kirkpatrick, 2007) which is comprised of 20 items such as, "Sex without love is OK." Responses range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree) and will be averaged, with higher scores indicating short-term mating orientation.

hypothesis.value: Short-term mating strategies (as opposed to long-term mating strategies) will significantly predict heavier alcohol use, which in turn will significantly predict more frequent risky sexual behavior.

q1.value: Effect of differnet feedback types on learning process of using Sensory Substitution Devices

q3.value:
We mesure differences in retention (accuracy in discrimination and recognition task) three months after training have been conducted, and compare the results  in three groups. First group has standard binary feedback each trial, second has standard feedback after every 3rd trial and the last has bandwidth feedback.

Our goal is to determine wether different feedback types has any effects on training effectivness in Sensory Substitution which may result in enchancing existng training paradigms and probably will help develop better Sensory Substitution Devices

The Idea came from Bertram and Staffrod article regarding hypothetical use of different training paradigms in sensory subsitution,  raporting that feedback is a factor, which has never been explored in Sensory substitution studies

q4.value:
1.(Main)  Retention in experimental groups will be better (better correct/false ratio) than in control group 
2.(secondary) In control group, learning process during training will be better(final correct/false ratio) than in experimental groups.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Methods

Participants.
The study is conducted on three groups of late blind people, 10 participants each. Each group corresponds to different condition – one control, and remaining two - experimental. In control condition participants are subjected to standard, frequent feedback(good or bad) after each trial. First experimental condition consist of feedback given every third trial with standard feedback. In the second experimental trial bandwidth feedback is given only when correct answers percentage is below 60% in discrimination task and 40% in recognition task in current trial.

Devices
We are using the vOICe Learning Edition as our sensory substitution software on computer screen. Participant is seated in front of computer and via headphones is subjected to auditory stimuli corresponding to different geometrical figures. In We are using PsychoPy as our experiment design software

Design
The training paradigm consists of standard recognition and discrimination tasks. In recognition task participant is given one of four geometric figures for 30s (circle, square, triangle and rectangle). After given time his task is to correctly recognise given geometry and say aloud its name. Discrimination task involve showing for 15 seconds one rectangle with different tilt, then for 5s mask and eventually discrimination where two rectangles (each differently tilted) are shown, one at the time, on left or right side of screen, of which only one was identical to first one. Participants could switch between one and the other using spacebar. They had 30s for recognition after which they decided by pressing left (for left rectangle) and right (for right rectangle).
Each task had 30 trials and whole session lasted for about an hour. The decision time for both tasks is indefinite. The session where conducted every day in the span of 3 weeks. After three months since the end of training participants where subjected to final test identical to one training session in order to determine whether any retention has transpired.


Analysis
	In order to assess learning efficiency we measured correctness in each trial in training session, and in experimental session. To measure and illustrate learning efficiency we use polynominal regression,(with second degree features) for each group. On account of low participants and risk of non-representative groups we use  Kruskal – Wallis ANOVA in order to check whether differences between groups are statistically significant. As our data analysis software we use scikit -learn. In addition we compare results of last training session with final test trial score (in each group separately). We are using Mann-Whitney u test in order to determine forgetting effect.

attributes.title: Radiation dose of prostatic artery embolisation for benign prostatic hyperplasia: protocol for a systematic review

q1.value: Radiation dose of prostatic artery embolisation for benign prostatic hyperplasia: protocol for a systematic review

q2.value: Valentin Zumstein, Jörg Binder, patrick betschart, Manolis Pratsinis, Gautier Müllhaupt, Lukas Hechelhammer, Hans-Peter Schmid, Dominik Abt

q3.value: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is a prevalent entity in elderly men and transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) still represents the gold standard of surgical treatment despite its considerable perioperative morbidity. Recently, prostatic artery embolization (PAE) was described as a novel effective and less invasive treatment alternative and evidence is growing including some prospective randomized controlled data which became available. Whereas efficacy of PAE is now a matter of fact, controversial discussions around the radiation dose which PAE patients are exposed to and its inherent stochastic and deterministic effects open the field for a systematic review of the current available literature.

q4.value:
Objectives (PICO):
Participants are patients with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) due to BPH.
Intervention will be PAE.
Primary Outcome is Radiation Dose (Dose Area Product) per patient.
Secondary Outcomes are:
Correlation of radiation exposure and:
-	prostate size
-	Age of participants
-	Fluoroscopy Time
-	Specifications of PAE (source of radiation, type of microcatheter, cone-beam ct use)

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We will conduct a systematic review following the PRISMA-P (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic review and Meta-Analysis Protocols) 2015 checklist:
- We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs) and prospective comparative trials as well as retrospective studies with at least 20 participants. All included trials report on primary or any secondary outcomes as defined above.  
- We will conduct a systematic search of three biomedical databases (York CRD, Embase, Medline) up to 17.01.2020.
- Records will be listed and stored in a citation software solution (Endnote TM)
Two independent reviewers will screen all titles and abstracts of all identified articles for appropriate study design and relevance of content. A third independent reviewer will solve disagreement. Trials that seem to meet inclusion criteria will then be reviewed as full text. 
Both reviewers will collect data using predefined data extraction sheets. Disagreements will be solved by a third independent reviewer.
Study design, baseline data, follow-up, outcomes and adverse events will be listed

attributes.title: Examining perceived ingroup similarity and outgroup dissimilarity as predictors of  religious intergroup bias
attributes.description: What role do differences/similarities in values play in predicting intergroup bias between atheists and Christians? A multiple regression and structural equation modeling analysis.

q1.value: Examining perceived ingroup similarity and outgroup dissimilarity as predictors of  religious intergroup bias

q3.value: Several past theories have emphasized the importance of perceived in-group similarity and out-group dissimilarity in understanding intergroup bias. Additionally, theories and research both suggest that similarity and dissimilarity in beliefs may be particularly important. Brandt & Van Tongeren (2017) have demonstrated that people high and low in religiosity are prejudiced toward other groups with dissimilar values. They have described the pattern of results as the religious values conflict model. The goal of the current research is to provide a more detailed understanding of the variables involved in the religious values conflict model. The proposed study was designed to provide a better understanding of the relationships between religiosity, perceived in-group/out-group (dis)similarity in values, and religious intergroup bias. The results of a pilot study were used to make confirmatory hypotheses with a priori predictions. Multiple regression analyses will be performed to replicate findings of the pilot study. Additionally, the mediation models from the pilot study had some limitations that should be addressed. For example, it is ideal to use latent variables with at least three indicators each in a structural equation model. The variables used in the mediation models for the pilot study did not have at least three indicators each. To address this, the proposed study will use measures of religiosity and dissimilarity with at least three indicators each.

q4.value:
Multiple regression in RStudio will be used to test the following hypotheses:
Hypothesis 1a: Similarity to atheists will be the best predictor of prejudice toward Christians (controlling for religiosity, dissimilarity to Christians, and demographic variables).
Hypothesis 1b: Similarity to Christians will be the best predictor of prejudice toward atheists (controlling for religiosity, dissimilarity to atheists, and demographic variables).
SEM mediation with bootstrapping in Amos Graphics will be used to test the following hypotheses:
Hypothesis 2a: Similarity to atheists will mediate the relationship between religiosity and prejudice toward Christians (the indirect effect of dissimilarity to Christians will not be significant).
Hypothesis 2b: Similarity to Christians will mediate the relationship between religiosity and prejudice toward atheists (the indirect effect of dissimilarity to atheists will not be significant).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Multiple regression with attitudes toward atheists regressed onto similarity to atheists, similarity to Christians, religiosity, and demographic variables. Multiple regression with attitudes toward Christians regressed onto similarity to atheists, similarity to Christians, religiosity, and demographic variables. Mediation with similarity to atheists mediating the relationship between religiosity and prejudice toward Christians. Mediation with similarity to Christians mediating the relationship between religiosity and prejudice toward atheists.

q9.value: Items will be randomized within questionnaires, questionnaires will be randomized within blocks, blocks will be randomized within the study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: I am collecting my data using a qualtrics survey. It will be distributed to adult MTurk workers from the United States. Participants will be credited $0.50 for participation. The survey will take less than 10 minutes. Participants will be included if they indicate that they are Christian or nonreligious. All other religious affiliations will be excluded from analysis. Participants will also be excluded if they have incomplete responses for key variables.

q13.value: There are two key factors for determining the sample size of this study. First, we must collect a large number of participants in order for structural equation modeling. Second, less than 75% of participants are likely to meet the criteria for inclusion. For these reasons, we aim to collect date from approximately 600 participants in order to have between 300 and 400 participants that satisfy our inclusion criteria.

q14.value: There are two key factors for determining the sample size of this study. First, we must collect a large number of participants in order for structural equation modeling. Second, less than 75% of participants are likely to meet the criteria for inclusion. For these reasons, we aim to collect date from approximately 600 participants in order to have between 300 and 400 participants that satisfy our inclusion criteria.

q15.value: We will stop after 600 participants and determine whether or not we have enough participants that meet inclusion criteria. If not, we will collect 50 more and check again. We will continue this process until we have approximately 300 to 400 participants who meet the inclusion criteria as well as a sufficient number of nonreligious participants.

question.value: No manipulated variables.

religiosity will be measured using the religious fundamentalism scale and the post-critical belief scale, similarity will be measured using a 4-item scale in which participants rate how similar/dissimilar a particular group is to themselves, prejudice is measured using thermometer/favorability ratings for different groups of people.

Religious fundamentalism scale items will be averaged to form a single score. Similarity items for each group will be averaged to form a single score for each target group. PCBS subscales will be used to create two dimensions as described in Grove et al., 2019.

Multiple regression in RStudio will be used to test the following hypotheses:
Hypothesis 1a: Similarity to atheists will be the best predictor of prejudice toward Christians (controlling for religiosity, dissimilarity to Christians, and demographic variables).
Hypothesis 1b: Similarity to Christians will be the best predictor of prejudice toward atheists (controlling for religiosity, dissimilarity to atheists, and demographic variables).
SEM mediation with bootstrapping in Amos Graphics will be used to test the following hypotheses:
Hypothesis 2a: Similarity to atheists will mediate the relationship between religiosity and prejudice toward Christians (the indirect effect of dissimilarity to Christians will not be significant).
Hypothesis 2b: Similarity to Christians will mediate the relationship between religiosity and prejudice toward atheists (the indirect effect of dissimilarity to atheists will not be significant).

q21.value: p-values (less than .05, two-tailed), confidence intervals (95% CI does not include zero), effect sizes (based on conventions for small, medium, and large) will be used for hypotheses 1a and 1b. SRMR, CFI, RMSEA, and TLI will be used for model fit indices for hypotheses 2a and 2b. p-values (less than 05, two-tailed), boot-strapped confidence intervales (95% CI does not include zero), and effect sizes (based on conventions for small, medium, and large) will be used for interpreting the mediation analyses for hypotheses 2a and 2b.

q22.value: Participants with incomplete or missing responses for important variables will not be included in the analyses.

q23.value: Participants with incomplete or missing responses for important variables will not be included in the analyses.

registration_responses.q12.question: I am collecting my data using a qualtrics survey. It will be distributed to adult MTurk workers from the United States. Participants will be credited $0.50 for participation. The survey will take less than 10 minutes. Participants will be included if they indicate that they are Christian or nonreligious. All other religious affiliations will be excluded from analysis. Participants will also be excluded if they have incomplete responses for key variables.

registration_responses.q17.question: religiosity will be measured using the religious fundamentalism scale and the post-critical belief scale, similarity will be measured using a 4-item scale in which participants rate how similar/dissimilar a particular group is to themselves, prejudice is measured using thermometer/favorability ratings for different groups of people.
registration_responses.q18.question: Religious fundamentalism scale items will be averaged to form a single score. Similarity items for each group will be averaged to form a single score for each target group. PCBS subscales will be used to create two dimensions as described in Grove et al., 2019.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Multiple regression in RStudio will be used to test the following hypotheses:

SEM mediation with bootstrapping in Amos Graphics will be used to test the following hypotheses:
Hypothesis 2a: Similarity to atheists will mediate the relationship between religiosity and prejudice toward Christians (the indirect effect of dissimilarity to Christians will not be significant).

attributes.title: Influence of dynamic visual stimuli on adults’ somatosensory processing.

q1.value: Influence of dynamic visual stimuli on adults’ somatosensory processing.

q2.value: Giulia Orioli, Jose van Velzen, Andrew J. Bremner

q3.value:
Peripersonal space is defined as the portion of space immediately surrounding our body (Rizzolatti, Fadiga, Fogassi, & Gallese, 1997), and its representations play important roles in our interactions with objects as well as other humans and in contributing to our ability to defend ourselves from impending threats. Importantly, they are foundational in constructing situated representations of our bodies and selves (Cléry & Ben Hamed, 2018; Vignemont & Iannetti, 2015).

Recently, research highlighted the intrinsic link between predictive mechanisms and peripersonal space conceptualisation. In particular, it has been suggested that peripersonal space itself could be defined by those predictive mechanisms that modulate the processing of tactile stimuli on the body when a visual, auditory or audiovisual stimulus is perceived near the body and moving towards it (Cléry & Ben Hamed, 2018; Kandula, Van der Stoep, Hofman, & Dijkerman, 2017; Serino et al., 2018).

In line with this, a number of studies investigated if tactile spatial attention could be modulated by predictive but not physically proximal stimuli presented in a different modality (Cléry, Guipponi, Odouard, Wardak, & Ben Hamed, 2015; Kandula, Hofman, & Dijkerman, 2015). The key novelty of these studies compared with previous research is their focus on moving visual stimuli that are not colocated nor synchronous with the tactile stimulus, but instead precede, and therefore predict it.

In the present project, we aim to investigate the neural correlates of these predictive processes, by measuring human adults’ electrophysiological responses to touches which are or are not predictable based on preceding dynamic visual displays. The project will include three studies, one of which is the subject of the present research plan preregistration. In this particular study, we will record and compare somatosensory evoked potentials (SEPs) in response to touches that have been preceded by approaching or receding dynamic visual information. Approaching visual motion could signal an impending contact between the moving object and the participant’s body, and a corresponding tactile stimulus, while this is not usually the case for receding motion. We will also explore any differences in the anticipatory event related potentials (ERPs) following the presentation of approaching vs receding visual displays, to investigate whether only approaching motion can lead to electrophysiological responses suggesting anticipation of a subsequent tactile stimulus.

q4.value:
With regards to the processing of the tactile stimulus, we are particularly interested in analysing the early components of the SEPs, those peaking within the first 500 ms following the onset of the tactile stimulus. We expect to find a difference in the amplitude of the components responding to the tactile stimulus following approaching vs receding visual displays, however we do not have any specific expectations with regards to the direction of the difference.

With regards to the anticipation of the tactile stimulus, we are particularly interested in the analysis of the modulation of the Contingent Negative Variation (CNV) after the presentation of approaching vs receding visual displays. The CNV is a slow, negative, fronto-central shift of the potential, which is thought to represent anticipatory activity. We expect that only the visual stimuli that are approaching (not receding from) the body will lead the participant to anticipate/predict a subsequent tactile stimulation. As a consequence, we expect to find a difference in the amplitude of the CNV following approaching vs receding visual displays. However, we do not have an expectation with regards to the direction of this difference.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
•	This study will be a part of a larger project comprising 3 studies (“Central” - the present study, “Uncrossed” and “Crossed”). All three studies will have the same core structure.
•	Each participant will take part in all of the studies, all of which will have within-subjects designs.
•	The order of presentation of the studies will be counterbalanced between participants, with the Central study being always either first or last.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value:
This preregistration is being submitted prior to the creation of the data: as of the date of submission of this research plan for preregistration, the data have not yet been collected, with the exception of 3 data samples, which have not yet been analysed. These 3 data samples (3 participants) have been collected with 2 main aims:
•	Verifying that the completion of the three studies within the project was sustainable for the participant without excessive fatigue and while maintaining high levels of alertness and accuracy. This proved possible, and therefore no changes to the data collection paradigm (see below) were required.
•	Verifying that enough data points (trials) could be collected that are artefact free and good quality. To do so, the data were pre-processed and the number of artefact free trials was confirmed. No further analytical steps (re-referencing and individual or grand averaging) have been performed. As a consequence, all researchers involved in the research are currently unaware of summary statistics or any pattern in the data.

question.value:
PARTICIPANTS
The final sample will include 20 participants, as determined by the power analyses reported below. The participants will take part in this study as well as the other two mentioned above (these other two studies are related to the present study and have its same core structure). The order of the studies will be counterbalanced across participants, with the present study being either the first or the last. The participants will be recruited from a sample of university students and adults who will express interest in taking part in the study and will receive either a monetary compensation for their time or credits from the Research Participation Scheme of the University of Birmingham. Ethical approval has been obtained from the Research Ethics Committee at the University of Birmingham, and Informed Consent will be obtained from the participants. The participants will be included in the final sample if: i) they contribute at least 50% artefact free trials, and ii) their accuracy level is at least 80%.

PROCEDURE AND STIMULI
The study includes four conditions: approaching visual stimulus followed by touch (Approaching Touch), approaching visual stimulus not followed by touch (Approaching No-Touch), receding visual stimulus followed by touch (Receding Touch) and receding visual stimulus not followed by touch (Receding No-Touch). Each of these conditions will be presented 42 times (168 trials in total). Trials will be presented in groups of 4, within which each condition will be presented in a random order, and grouped in 14 blocks of 3 groups of 4 trials each.

At the beginning of each block, the participant will be presented with a target face (male or female, counterbalanced across participants irrespective of their own gender) for 5 s to memorise. The participant will then be instructed to hold their hands close to each other and to focus their attention on a fixation cross at the top of the screen throughout the block. The fixation cross will be replaced by a face for 200 ms during the inter-trial intervals (ITIs). The participant will be told that their task is to decide, at the end of each block, whether the target face that they memorised was among those presented during the ITIs and, at the same time, to ignore any other stimuli. The participant will be informed that they are expected to maintain fixation on the fixation cross throughout and that their eyes will be monitored. The ITIs will have a jittered duration between 800 and 1000 ms, inclusive of the 200 ms in which the face is presented. The ITI will be followed by the presentation, at the bottom of the screen, of a small red ball moving either towards the participant’s hands or towards the background. When the ball will move towards the participant’s hands (Approaching conditions), it will simulate, across 10 images and 20 frames (333.3 ms) a motion trajectory from the background towards the participant’s hands, disappearing at the halfway point. More specifically, the ball will reach the halfway point on the 9th frame (after 297 ms) and then it will start disappearing from the 10th frame. When the ball will move towards the background (Receding conditions), it will simulate a motion trajectory from the participant’s hands towards the background, starting at the halfway point. Once the ball will disappear, the participant will receive, on 50% of the trials, a vibrotactile stimulus on both hands, lasting 100 ms. The tactile stimulus will be presented after an interval lasting as long as the motion (297 ms), and therefore at the expected time to contact of the simulated moving ball with the hands in the Approaching condition.

Throughout the study the participant will sit in front of a 21” screen in a dimly lit room. Their hands will be resting next to each other on a small table in front of them and will be positioned about 25.5 cm from the screen and 5 cm below it: this is the location where the simulated moving ball would collide with the hands should it continue its trajectory. The vibrotactile stimulus will be delivered to the participant’s hands via custom-built voice coil tactile stimulators (tactors), driven by a 220 Hz sine wave. One tactor will be placed in each hand and fixed to the participant’s palms with self-adherent bandage. In order to mask the noise of the tactors, white noise will be presented to the participant via earphones.

EEG RECORDING
The participants’ electrical brain activity will be continuously recorded using a Hydrocel Geodesic Sensor Net (Electrical Geodesic Inc.), consisting of 128 silver-silver chloride electrodes evenly distributed across the scalp. The vertex will serve as the reference. The electrical potential will be digitized at 500 Hz sampling rate and stored for off-line analyses (Hoehl & Wahl, 2012).

ANALYSES
The raw data will be processed offline using NetStation 5.4.2 analysis software (Electrical Geodesic Inc.). Continuous EEG data will be high-pass filtered at 0.03 Hz and low-pass filtered at 30 Hz using digital elliptical filtering (Hoehl & Wahl, 2012). The recordings will then be segmented in epochs, from 800 ms before the tactile stimulus onset until 1200 ms after it and baseline-corrected to the average amplitude of the 100 ms interval preceding the stimulus onset (either the visual or the tactile stimulus, depending on the analyses - see below). Extending to 800 ms prior to the tactile stimulus onset, the epochs will include the presentation of the visual stimulus and the interval between its disappearance and the onset of the tactile stimulus. Channels showing low activity (voltage step smaller than 0.5 μV within a sliding window of 80 ms), or voltage steps larger than 125 μV within a sliding window of 20 ms or larger than 200 μV within a sliding window of 80 ms will be marked as bad. Epochs containing more than 13 bad channels will be rejected, as well as epochs containing eye blinks and eye movements during the presentation of the visual stimulus (600 to 300 ms prior to the tactile stimulus onset). Bad channels (if less than 13) will be interpolated on an epoch-by-epoch basis using spherical interpolation of neighbouring channel values. Artefact free data will then be re-referenced to the average potential over the scalp. Finally, individual and grand averages will be calculated.

q13.value: The final sample will include 20 participants. As well as taking part in this study, each participant will also take part in the other two studies mentioned above (see data collection procedures above). Each participant will be included in the final sample if: i) they contribute at least 50% artefact free trials, and ii) their accuracy level is at least 80%. Should any participant not reach the required accuracy level or number of artefact-free trials, that participant will be removed from the sample and replaced with a newly recruited participant until the final sample size of 20 participants is reached (with all reaching the required accuracy level and number of artefact-free trials).

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis to determine the number of participants that would be required to obtain a statistically significant result given an anticipated medium effect size of dz = .7. We estimated this effect size based on a recent study (Rigato, Bremner, Gillmeister, & Banissy, 2019), which investigated SEPs in adults using an EEG system similar to ours. The effect sizes reported by Rigato et al. (2019) were between dz = .55 and dz = 1.5. (medium and large), so our power analysis assumed a medium effect size dz = .7, with α = .05 and β = .8, on the basis of a paired samples t-test. This power analysis, conducted using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007), determined that in order to obtain a meaningful statistically significant result we would need a sample of 19 participants. In order to properly counterbalance the conditions the order of presentations of the studies within the project, we decided to obtain a sample of 20 participants.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated when the sample size indicated by the power analysis above has been collected. At that point, the data will be preprocessed and the level of accuracy and the number of artefact free trials per participant will be confirmed. Should any participant not reach the required accuracy level or number of artefact-free trials, that participant will be removed from the sample and replaced with a newly recruited participant until the final sample size of 20 participants is reached (with all participants reaching the required accuracy level and number of artefact-free trials).

question.value: The study includes two manipulated variables: the motion direction of the visual stimulus (approaching vs receding) and the presence vs absence of a subsequent tactile stimulus.

Our main aim is to compare how the adult brain responds to tactile stimuli preceded by (unattended) approaching or receding visual stimuli. Therefore, we will record ERPs originating from sites close to somatosensory areas. As stated in the hypotheses section, we will focus on comparing the modulations of the recorded electrical potential in response to the touch (SEPs) and in anticipation of the touch (CNV).

For the analyses of the SEP components, we want to provide a pure measure of adults’ brain responses to the tactile stimuli alone, unpolluted by any other aspects of the stimulation (e.g. the visual stimuli). To this end, we will compute two difference waveforms subtracting, for each visual motion direction condition (Approaching vs Receding), the response recorded in the No-Touch condition (which is visual information alone) from the response recorded in the Touch condition (which is tactile and visual information). We will then average the difference waves and inspect the averaged topographic maps representing the scalp distribution of the electrical activity (Luck & Gaspelin, 2017), in order to identify the presence of hotspots in the regions surrounding CP3 and CP4 in the 10-20 system. Then, we will visually inspect the averaged recordings from the electrodes within these hotspots. From these averaged recordings we will then isolate, for each hemisphere, a cluster of few electrodes showing the most pronounced SEP components (Rigato et al., 2017). In order to avoid biased measurements, the exact time window containing each component of interest will be determined by averaging the waveforms across participants and conditions (Luck & Gaspelin, 2017). We will then calculate the mean individual amplitude of the difference waves across the electrode clusters and within the time window of interest, and compare the response to the touch when it was preceded by approaching vs receding visual displays.

For the analysis of the CNV component, we are interested in comparing the Approaching and Receding trials, irrespective of whether the motion will be followed by a touch or not. To this end, we will compute the averaged waveform of the responses in the approaching and receding trials, irrespective of whether the motion will be followed by a touch or not. We will then identify the electrode clusters and time windows of interest following the same procedure as described above. We will then calculate the mean individual amplitude for each motion direction and compare the activity between the approaching vs receding conditions.

As stated above, for the SEP components we will compute and then compare two difference waveforms subtracting, for each visual motion direction condition (Approaching vs Receding), the responses recorded in the No-Touch condition from the responses recorded in the Touch condition. The difference waves obtained will represent the SEPs to the touch itself, irrespective of all other aspects of the stimulation. For the CNV component, instead, we will compute and then compare the averaged waveform of the responses in the approaching and receding trials, irrespective of whether the motion will be followed by a touch or not.
Paired planned comparisons (t-tests) will be used to compare the mean individual amplitude of the recorded waveforms within each component of interest.

q21.value: Two tailed tests will be used for each analysis and inferences will be made based on p-values (α < .05) and effect sizes (dz).

q22.value: Participants will be excluded if: i) they do not contribute at least 50% artefact free trials, or ii) their accuracy level is lower than 80%. This decision will be made prior to the analysis of the data and these participants will be replaced by newly recruited participants until we reach a final sample of 20 participants (see Sample size rationale and Stopping rule above).

q24.value: We plan to visually inspect the topography of the EEG recordings to identify any interesting yet unexpected components. Should any such components be found, we will run exploratory analyses to investigate the presence of any differences between conditions.

We will then average the difference waves and inspect the averaged topographic maps representing the scalp distribution of the electrical activity (Luck & Gaspelin, 2017), in order to identify the presence of hotspots in the regions surrounding CP3 and CP4 in the 10-20 system. Then, we will visually inspect the averaged recordings from the electrodes within these hotspots. From these averaged recordings we will then isolate, for each hemisphere, a cluster of few electrodes showing the most pronounced SEP components (Rigato et al., 2017). In order to avoid biased measurements, the exact time window containing each component of interest will be determined by averaging the waveforms across participants and conditions (Luck & Gaspelin, 2017). We will then calculate the mean individual amplitude of the difference waves across the electrode clusters and within the time window of interest, and compare the response to the touch when it was preceded by approaching vs receding visual displays.

For the analysis of the CNV component, we are interested in comparing the Approaching and Receding trials, irrespective of whether the motion will be followed by a touch or not. To this end, we will compute the averaged waveform of the responses in the approaching and receding trials, irrespective of whether the motion will be followed by a touch or not. We will then identify the electrode clusters and time windows of interest following the same procedure as described above. We will then calculate the mean individual amplitude for each motion direction and compare the activity between the approaching vs receding conditions.
registration_responses.q18.question: As stated above, for the SEP components we will compute and then compare two difference waveforms subtracting, for each visual motion direction condition (Approaching vs Receding), the responses recorded in the No-Touch condition from the responses recorded in the Touch condition. The difference waves obtained will represent the SEPs to the touch itself, irrespective of all other aspects of the stimulation. For the CNV component, instead, we will compute and then compare the averaged waveform of the responses in the approaching and receding trials, irrespective of whether the motion will be followed by a touch or not.
registration_responses.q19.question: Paired planned comparisons (t-tests) will be used to compare the mean individual amplitude of the recorded waveforms within each component of interest.

q1.value: Response Time Autocorrelation in Dot-motion Discrimination

q3.value: Dot-motion discrimination requires participants to detect the motion of a set of coherently moving dots within a field of randomly moving distractor dots (a type of visual stimulus also known as a random dot kinematogram). It is just one of many different perceptual categorization tasks that could be used to investigate the hypothesis driving this preregistered research, which seeks to determine how rewards affect perceptual decision making. Behavior in perceptual decision tasks can be modeled by sequential sampling models such as the drift-diffusion model (DDM). The DDM (Ratcliff, Smith, Brown & McKoon, 2016) fits complete reaction time distributions and successfully explains human speed-accuracy tradeoffs in two-choice perceptual tasks. The effect of rewards on behavior is not modeled by the DDM in its standard formulation. However, when the model's decision boundaries (a.k.a. "thresholds") are set to be inversely proportional to a leaky integral of the reward rate (e.g., the number of correct responses per second), the resulting model (Simen, Cohen & Holmes, 2006; Simen & Cohen, 2009) can adapt its speed-accuracy tradeoff so as to nearly maximize the rate of rewards being earned from performance. Reward rates are heavily influenced by the response-to-stimulus interval (RSI) of a task (Bogacz, Brown, Moehlis, Holmes & Cohen, 2006):  longer RSIs generally reduce reward rates for the model and for experimental participants by lengthening the time between rewards, and they also cause the reward-rate-optimal speed-accuracy tradeoff to shift toward accuracy and away from speed. Participants often show evidence of optimizing speed-accuracy tradeoffs so as to maximize reward rates accordingly (e.g, Simen, Contreras, Buck, Hu, Holmes & Cohen, 2009). When the RSI changes, however, it takes time to optimize using this inverse-proportional threshold algorithm: reward rates build up or decay to new asymptotic levels over several trials, which causes decision boundaries to decay or build, respectively, over the same time period. This has the effect of increasing the model's response time autocorrelation, while at the same time strengthening the negative cross-correlation of the model's response times with its reward rates. We designed a random dot-motion experiment to test these predictions of the model, as well as to test whether reward magnitudes (e.g., points or dollars per correct response) affect decision boundary setting. The experiment presents participants with simple visual stimuli of dots randomly moving to the left or right. Participants are rewarded for correct responses with either one or two points. The key independent variables are the RSI, the reward magnitude for left or right, and the frequency with which RSI and reward magnitude change within the course of a block of trials.

q4.value:
1. Relative to task conditions in which average RSIs are constant, task conditions in which RSIs are dynamic should produce stronger response time autocorrelation (higher correlation coefficients at each trial lag). 
2. Larger reward magnitudes should produce faster responding and stronger response biases. 
3. Participants should approximately optimize starting point and decision bound parameters of a drift-diffusion model fitted to performance data, converging on values that maximize reward rates given fitted drift parameters.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: This is a repeated-measures within-participants design. There is no treatment group. All participants will experience all conditions of the experiment. Participants will not know the research objective or hypothesis.

question.value:
Within-subject design with 2 factors, factorially combined: 
1. response-to-stimulus interval (RSI) by duration in 3 levels: average 1 second, average 2 seconds, and dynamic*; 
2. reward magnitude for correct responses in 4 levels: equally valued/1 point per correct response, equally valued/2 point per correct response, unequally valued/ 1 versus 2 points, and dynamic. 

*"Dynamic" refers to task conditions in which RSI or reward magnitude is held constant for a geometrically distributed number of trials, then is randomly shifted to a new value and held constant for a geometrically distributed number of trials. The mean run-length of trials over which task conditions are held constant is 10. 

We counterbalance the assignment of larger reward to left or right responses in the unequal and dynamic reward conditions. We randomize the task condition order in every session for each participant. Participants return for multiple sessions to reduce the impact of practice effects on behavior patterns.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Data for this experiment do not exist. However, we may include autocorrelation analyses of previously published data in our writeup of our new results.

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through advertisements at poster boards on the Oberlin College campus and in local shops and restaurants, as well as on the Oberlin College Classified ad website. 
Participants will be paid $8-$12 for agreeing to participate in each session, depending on the number of correct responses they make: the more points they earn in the task, the more they will be paid. They will be asked to return for at least 5 sessions.  Participants must be at least 18 years old and under 30 years old to eliminate any response time differences caused by aging.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 10 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 12, assuming that not all will complete the total task. Each participant will make roughly 1000 responses per hour-long session, and we are aiming for 5 sessions per participant.

q14.value:
Three factors determine our desired sample size:
1) We have previously found this number of participants and sessions to provide sufficient power to detect autocorrelations in response time data in both model simulations and human empirical data (Simen, Contreras, Buck, Hu, Holmes & Cohen, 2009).
2) Practice effects are dramatically diminished after a few hour-long sessions of the task, and five sessions has been sufficient in the past to observe significant autocorrelations that are not necessarily due to practice effects
3) This research will be carried out by an undergraduate student under the Principal Investigator's supervision. If participants drop out, or if the research student cannot complete it, then this could lead to a smaller sample size than desired. Five sessions per participant has been effective in the past for preventing drop-out while still yielding enough power to detect significant results.

q15.value: If participants drop out of the study prior to the completion of five sessions, we may opt to replace them with new participants, in order to reach our goal of 10 participants and five sessions per participant.

question.value: For each trial, we will measure a participant's response time in milliseconds, accuracy (correct or not), and choice of left or right.

We will measure the mean and median of the response time. We will also analyze the local response time, accuracy, choice proportion (percentage of left or right) using leaky integral (low-pass filter) or sliding time window-based averaging.  Time window lengths and leaky integral half-life durations will be 2, 5, and 10 times the average duration of a trial in each condition.

1. We will do an autocorrelation analysis of response time with the following trial-lag levels: 5,10 and 50. We will also measure the cross-correlation of response times and reward rates.

2. We will use a Bayesian paired t-test and the Mann–Whitney U test (nonparametric) to test whether there is a significant difference in correlation coefficients between different conditions at each trial-lag, and globally. We will determine whether the correlation coefficient of autocorrelation is significantly larger than 0 and whether the reward-rate/response-time cross-correlation is significantly smaller than 0. 

3. We will analyze fitted drift-diffusion model (DDM) parameters for 1s and 2s RSI conditions using a parametric bootstrap test and a Bayesian t-test, to determine whether parameters differ between conditions.

4. We will fit the DDM using Bayesian hierarchical methods, the Dynamic Models of Choice (DMC) software (Heathcote et al., 2019), and for comparison purposes, the Hierarchical Drift-Diffusion Model (HDDM) software (Wiecki, Sofer & Frank, 2013). We will also use the EZ-diffusion (Wagenmakers, van der Maas & Grasman, 2007) and EZ2 (Grasman, Wagnemakers & van der Maas, 2009) methods, which are simpler, faster, less accurate, but also possibly better for inference about DDM parameter changes across conditions (Dutilh et al., 2019).

q20.value:
We will transform the accuracy into the reward rate estimates using two approaches: 
1) exponential function convolved with the times of correct responses (also known as a leaky integral or low-pass filter). A set of exponential parameters or time constants that determine the half-life of the exponential function will be utilized: 2/5/10 times the average duration of a trial in each condition.
2) sliding-window approach with different window lengths of 2/5/10 times the average duration of a trial in each condition.

q21.value:
1. We will use the Bayes factors greater than 3 to accept the null hypothesis of no difference and Bayes factors less than 1/3 to accept the alternative hypothesis. 
2. We will use the standard p < .05 criterion for determining if the one-tailed t-test suggests that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. 
3. We will use 95% confidence intervals and credible intervals to aid in inference.

q22.value:
1. We will exclude responses with response times that are too fast from DDM fitting. We will define 'too fast' to be 200 msec. If DDM fitting times are not prohibitive, we will also repeat the analysis with a 175 msec criterion. Fitting using Bayesian hierarchical methods can take weeks for comparably sized data sets with the computational power available to us). 

2. Responses with response times greater than 4 or 5 times the standard deviation above the mean will be excluded for DDM fitting.

3. Participants who do not exceed 60% accuracy will be excluded from the analysis. 

4. We may exclude the first 2 sessions from some analyses to account for practice effects.

q23.value: Participants who do not complete at least 3 sessions will be excluded.

q25.value:
References

Dutilh, G. et al. (2019). The Quality of Response Time Data Inference: A Blinded, Collaborative Assessment of the Validity of Cognitive Models, Psychonomic Bulletin & Review, 26:1051–1069

Grasman, R. P., Wagenmakers, E.-J., & van der Maas, H. L. (2009). On the mean and variance of response times under the diffusion model with an application to parameter estimation. Journal of Mathematical Psychology, 53:55-68.

Heathcote, A., Lin, Y.-S., Reynolds, A., Strickland, L., Gretton, M. and Matzke, D. (2019). Dynamic models of choice, Behavior Research Methods, 51:961-985.

Simen, P., Cohen, J. D., and Holmes, P. (2006). Rapid decision threshold modulation by reward rate in a neural network. Neural Networks, 19:1013-1026. 

Simen, P. and Cohen, J. D. (2009). Explicit melioration by a neural diffusion model. Brain Research, 1299:95-117.

Simen, P., Contreras, D., Buck, C., Hu, P., Holmes, P. and Cohen, J. D. (2009). Reward-rate optimization in two-alternative decision making: Empirical tests of theoretical predictions. Journal of Experimental Psychology: Human Perception and Performance, 35:1865-1897.

attributes.title: Reliability of area-based and distance-based spatial summation of pain using electrocutaneus stimuli
attributes.description: The projects is about reliability of spatial summation of pain, a paradigm which is believed to reflect pain modulation in humans.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value:
Reliability of area-based and distance-based spatial summation of pain using electrocutaneous stimuli

Author(s):

Wacław M. Adamczyk1,3, Christin Domeier1, Linn Manthey1, Tibor Szikszay1,2, Kerstin Luedtke1,2,3.

1Department of Health Sciences, Academic Physiotherapy, Pain and Exercise Research Luebeck (P.E.R.L), University of Luebeck, Luebeck, Germany.
2Department of Systems Neuroscience, University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf, Hamburg, Germany.
3Laboratory of Pain Research, Institute of Physiotherapy and Health Sciences, The Jerzy Kukuczka Academy of Physical Education, Katowice, Poland.

other.value:
After the end of the study, participants will answer the series of manipulation check questions. They will be asked about the study aim, hypotheses tested in the study and they will be debriefed in terms of a number of electrodes stimulated. Post-hoc expectations about pain levels when different stimulation areas or distances between electrodes are applied will be collected.

Registration is valid because the procedure was only piloted so far on 5 healthy participants.

sample.value:
A sample size of 24 subjects was chosen to counterbalance all of the conditions (e.g. order of the paradigms) across participants. The sample is slightly higher than the one calculated for the purpose of a previous investigation using electrocutaneous stimuli (see Holbert et al., 2017).

Holbert MD, Pedler A, Camfermann D, Harvie DS. Comparison of spatial summation properties at different body sites. Scand J Pain. 2017, 17:126-131.

analyses.value:
Spatial summation of pain will be determined by comparing pain elicited by one electrode to pain originating from activation of two up to 5 electrodes (AB) or by comparing pain elicited by one electrode to pain originated from activation of pair of two electrodes with different distances (0, 1, 2, 3cm).

Q1 will be addressed by General Linear Model with within-subjects’ factors “paradigm” (AB, DB), “pain” (30/100, 50/100, 70/100), “space” (1, 2, 3, 4, 5). Significant “pain” x “space” interaction will justify H1 (p < 0.05).

Q2 will be addressed by the intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC). Within-day intra-examiner reliability will be tested by correlating data from session 1 with data from session 2. Between-day intra-examiner reliability will be tested by correlating data from session 1 with data from session 3. The analysis will be run for a single measurement, mean of 2 and mean of 3 measurements.

outliers.value: Subjects who do not attend the third session, will not be considered in between-day reliability analysis.

dependent.value: Pain intensity will be measured by a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) ranging from 0 (no pain) to 100 (worst pain imaginable).

conditions.value:
One cohort of healthy participants will be examined in three different sessions, i.e. two sessions on day 1, and one session on day 2 (one day after). During each of the sessions, SSp will be assessed using two paradigms: area-based (AB) and distance-based (DB) SSp. Each paradigm will be repeated using three different within-subject conditions:
a) Pain 30 - stimuli individually calibrated to induce pain corresponding to pain at the level of 30 on a VAS scale
b) Pain 50 - stimuli individually calibrated to induce pain corresponding to pain at the level of 50 on the VAS scale
c) Pain 70 - stimuli individually calibrated to induce pain corresponding to pain at the level of 70 on the VAS scale
Each condition will include exposure to 5 different electrocutaneous stimuli (different in terms of area stimulated or distance between stimuli). Each stimulus will be repeated three times. Thus, every participant will receive 90 stimuli per session:
5 electrocutaneous stimuli x 3 repetitions x 3 conditions (pain 30, 50, 70) x 2 paradigms (AB, DB).

hypothesis.value:
1) What's the main question being asked or hypothesis being tested in this study?
Q1: Does stimulus intensity affect the magnitude of spatial summation of pain (SSp) in healthy volunteers?
Q2: What is the reliability of distance-based and area-based spatial summation paradigms?
H1: Pain intensity affects the magnitude of SSp
H2: SSp is reliable when at least two measurements are performed

Spatial summation of pain will be determined by comparing pain elicited by one electrode to pain originating from activation of two up to 5 electrodes (AB) or by comparing pain elicited by one electrode to pain originated from activation of pair of two electrodes with different distances (0, 1, 2, 3cm).

Q1 will be addressed by General Linear Model with within-subjects’ factors “paradigm” (AB, DB), “pain” (30/100, 50/100, 70/100), “space” (1, 2, 3, 4, 5). Significant “pain” x “space” interaction will justify H1 (p < 0.05).

Q2 will be addressed by the intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC). Within-day intra-examiner reliability will be tested by correlating data from session 1 with data from session 2. Between-day intra-examiner reliability will be tested by correlating data from session 1 with data from session 3. The analysis will be run for a single measurement, mean of 2 and mean of 3 measurements.
registration_responses.outliers: Subjects who do not attend the third session, will not be considered in between-day reliability analysis.
registration_responses.dependent: Pain intensity will be measured by a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) ranging from 0 (no pain) to 100 (worst pain imaginable).
registration_responses.conditions:
One cohort of healthy participants will be examined in three different sessions, i.e. two sessions on day 1, and one session on day 2 (one day after). During each of the sessions, SSp will be assessed using two paradigms: area-based (AB) and distance-based (DB) SSp. Each paradigm will be repeated using three different within-subject conditions:
a) Pain 30 - stimuli individually calibrated to induce pain corresponding to pain at the level of 30 on a VAS scale
b) Pain 50 - stimuli individually calibrated to induce pain corresponding to pain at the level of 50 on the VAS scale
c) Pain 70 - stimuli individually calibrated to induce pain corresponding to pain at the level of 70 on the VAS scale
Each condition will include exposure to 5 different electrocutaneous stimuli (different in terms of area stimulated or distance between stimuli). Each stimulus will be repeated three times. Thus, every participant will receive 90 stimuli per session:
5 electrocutaneous stimuli x 3 repetitions x 3 conditions (pain 30, 50, 70) x 2 paradigms (AB, DB).
registration_responses.hypothesis:
1) What's the main question being asked or hypothesis being tested in this study?
Q1: Does stimulus intensity affect the magnitude of spatial summation of pain (SSp) in healthy volunteers?
Q2: What is the reliability of distance-based and area-based spatial summation paradigms?
H1: Pain intensity affects the magnitude of SSp
H2: SSp is reliable when at least two measurements are performed

attributes.title: The Influence of Isometric Exercises and the Cold Pressor Task on Offset Analgesia

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value:
The Influence of Isometric Exercises and the Cold Pressor Task on Offset Analgesia

Authors: Tibor Szikszay a, b, Waclaw Adamczyk a, c, Alexandra Hoegner a, Nele Woermann a, Kerstin Luedtke a, b, c

a)	Department of Health Sciences, Academic Physiotherapy, Pain and Exercise Research Luebeck (P.E.R.L), University of Luebeck, Luebeck, Germany.
b)	Department of Systems Neuroscience, University Medical Center Hamburg-Eppendorf, Hamburg, Germany.
c)	Laboratory of Pain Research, Institute of Physiotherapy and Health Sciences, The Jerzy Kukuczka Academy of Physical Education, Katowice, Poland.

sample.value: The expected sample size is n=75 (n=25 in each condition).

analyses.value:
To identify the magnitude of offset analgesia, the difference in pain between the constant trial and the offset trial will be determined based on average pain ratings of relating intervals. The primary endpoint is the difference in offset analgesia between groups during the interventions. If sufficient homoscedasticity and normal distribution are present, offset analgesia data will be analyzed using a General Linear Model with the between-subjects factor "group" (cold pain, exercise, rest) and within-subjects factors "time" (before, during, afterward) and "location" (affected forearm, non-affected forearm). 

If necessary, an identical analysis is performed with potential confounders to adjust the results. Furthermore, the seconds until the minimum pain ratings will be analyzed.

outliers.value: There will be no exclusion of outliers.

dependent.value: For the Offset analgesia paradigm, the following two heat stimuli trials will be applied in a counterbalanced order to the dominant volar forearm: 1. Constant trial (CT): 40 seconds with individual test temperature (pain50), 2. Offset trial (OT): 15 seconds pain50 (T1) followed by 10 seconds of pain50 + 1,5°C (T2) and again 15 seconds of pain50 (T3). Subjects will provide continuous ratings of pain intensity (computerized visual analogue scale) during every stimulus (CT, OT).

conditions.value: Healthy pain-free participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups (cold pain, training, rest). The 'cold pain group' will be exposed to the task of immersing one hand in cold water for 3 minutes (Cold Pressor Task, CPT), while the 'training group' is asked to perform an isometric grip exercise for 3 minutes. There will be no manipulation in the control group. Each intervention is performed twice (dominant, non-dominant forearm). Offset analgesia will be measured three times in each condition (group) at the dominant forearm: immediately before, during (60 seconds after the start of intervention) and when the pain has worn off.

hypothesis.value:
Q1: Does acute experimentally induced cold pain or isometric exercise modulate the magnitude of offset analgesia?
Q2: Are there region-specific differences between the affected (painful) and the unaffected forearm regarding the magnitude of offset analgesia?

H1: Offset analgesia is modulated by both the cold pain and the isometric exercises.
H2: There are region-specific differences between the affected and unaffected side.

study_type_other.value: The data collection has started but was not analyzed yet.

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

attributes.title: Transcribed chats
attributes.description: Face-to-face and text-based chat expression styles transcribed.

q1.value: Transcribed online chat and FtF discussions

q2.value: Carla Anne Roos, Namkje Koudenburg, Tom Postmes

q3.value: The style of expression in online discussions appears to be very different from face-to-face conversations. Recent research found that text-based online expression is relatively clear and unresponsive, and that this might negatively affect the degree of consensus and solidarity experienced by conversation partners. However, there are many more differences between communication media that could potentially affect experiences of consensus and solidarity. In two studies, we aimed to isolate the effects of expression style from other characteristic of the medium (e.g., anonymity). In order to do this, we varied the expression style within communication media. In a previous study we reproduced the expression styles characteristic of text-based online chats and face-to-face discussions in a face-to-face format by asking actors to enact transcripts of both and showing these enactments to observers. The proposed study will complement this previous study by presenting observers with text-based online and face-to-face discussions in a chat format.

q4.value:
1) Participants will rate the online chat transcripts as relatively a) clear and b) unresponsive compared to the transcribed face-to-face conversations.
2) Participants will rate the interaction partners in the online chat transcripts as experiencing a) less consensus and b) less solidarity than the interaction partners in the transcribed face-to-face conversations.
3) Rated clarity and unresponsiveness will negatively predict rated consensus and solidarity.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Participants will be unaware of the fact that they will read one transcribed face-to-face discussion and one text-based online chat discussion. The layout of both types of discussions  might lead them to the conclusion that both are online chats.

question.value: The study has a repeated measures design with two conditions. Specifically, participants will see both a transcribed face-to-face and a transcribed text-based online chat discussion. Participants will be randomly assigned to condition order. The discussions are taken from a previous study in which groups of three students discussed about a controversial issue with a research confederate who introduced dissent. They did this in two conditions: via text-based online chat and face-to-face. We selected two group that were representative of the communication medium condition effects observed in that study. Participants in the current study will be presented with an online questionnaire in which the transcripts are embedded. The discussions will have the layout of an online chat where icons represent conversation partners, but otherwise could equally well classify as transcribed FtF discussions. They will be asked to read the conversations carefully and answer some questions about each in turn.

q9.value: We will use an automated simple randomization, executed by the questionnaire software (Qualtrics).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from the Dutch first year psychology student pool. These participants can opt in to participate in the study if Dutch is their native language.  They will receive partial course credit for their participation.

q14.value: The previous study had a similar design and 103 participants.

question.value:
By transcribing face-to-face and online chat discussions we manipulate expression style: face-to-face is relatively vague and responsive and online is relatively clear and unresponsive. 

As written before, the transcripts were selected from a previous study because they were representative for the condition effects found in that study. Specifically, we chose two groups that scored average on the composite variable consisting of the five dependent variables with the biggest effect size of condition (the five variables that differentiated most between conditions). The transcripts all concern a different discussion topic, but topics are similar and we did not find any effects for topic in the previous study.

In transcribing the discussions, we attempted to keep them as close to the original conversations as possible. In the chats, we only corrected spelling errors, replaced the (one) emoji with "haha", and wrote out abbreviations, in order to remove these possible confounds. In the face-to-face discussions, we placed comma's where there were speaking turns to make reading easier, removed interrupted phrases and wrote out overlapping speaking turns as if they followed each other to preserve the flow of the discussions that was present in the audio-recordings. In both conversations we added capital letters and left out periods, except if they were present in the text-based chat.

All the following variables will be tested on five-point likert scales, ranging from completely disagree to completely agree. All items will be presented to participants in Dutch.

* Perceived conversational flow: how smooth and coordinated the conversation was. Items are: This conversation was ...smooth/... difficult/ ...pleasant/ ...harmonious.
* Perceived clarity of expression: how clear interaction partners expressed themselves. Items are: During this conversation, the group members expressed themselves clearly/ ...the opinions of group members were vague/ ...the group members expressed themselves forcefully. This will be combined with the average rating of clarity of opinion expression of each individual group member (this will be a seven-point likert scale).
* Perceived responsiveness: how much interaction partners responded to each other's comments. Group members ...listened to each other/  ... ignored each other/ ...cross talked.
* Perceived consensus: how much consensus/agreement there was among interaction partners. Items are: In this conversation, the group members ...understood each other/ ...were on the same wavelength/ ...agreed with each other.
* Perceived solidarity: how good the relationship between interaction partners was. Items are: During this conversation ...group members identified with each other/ ...the mutual relations in the group were good/ ...I experienced a sense of oneness among group members/ ...I felt the group members were a unit/ ...I felt the group members could act as one. 
* Perceived inhibition: how polite and considerate interaction partners were.  Items are: During this conversation ...I thought the group members were polite/ ...I thought the group members were superficial as if they lacked depth/ ...I was interested in what the group members had to say/ ...the group members thought well before they spoke.
* We will also ask participants to indicate each group member's opinion on the discussed statement.
We will calculate the mean scores of the items.

Repeated measures ANOVA's to test the differences in clarity, unresponsiveness, consensus and solidarity between conditions.
Repeated measures regressions with perceived clarity and unresponsiveness as fixed effect predictors and perceived consensus and solidarity as dependent variables, nested in the random factor of participant ID.

q21.value:
For the effect of condition, we will report the ANOVA F-test with a cutoff p-value of .05. We will also report means and 95% confidence intervals of the conditions. We will also include a measure of effect size, either R2 or Cohen's d. 
For the regression, we will look at beta-coefficients and use a cutoff p-value of .05.

q22.value:
We will exclude participants that are not native Dutch or Muslim, because the conversations are in Dutch and one of the discussions is about mosques.
We will look for multivariate outliers.
I will do awareness checks to test whether participants read the transcripts, and exclude participants that fail these.

q23.value: I will delete participants that do not complete the entire questionnaire.

q24.value: Exploratory analyses on perceived inhibition and conversational flow, using repeated measures ANOVA's and repeated measures mediation analyses where these variables are used as mediator in the regressions predicting perceived consensus and solidarity with perceived clarity and unresponsiveness.

q25.value:
This study builds on:
Roos, C.A., Postmes, T., & Koudenburg, N. (2019). The micro-dynamics of social regulation: Comparing the navigation of disagreement in text-based online and face-to-face communication. Manuscript submitted for publication.
Roos, C.A., Koudenburg, N., & Postmes, T. (2019). Online social regulation: When everyday diplomatic skills of harmonious disagreement break down. Manuscript submitted for publication.
